Said * Mohamed Abd El-Aal Catalysis and Surface Chemistry Lab, Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Assiut University, Assiut, 71516, Egypt Catalysis and Surface Chemistry Lab Chemistry Department Faculty of Science Assiut University Assiut 71516 Egypt Catalysis and Surface Chemistry Lab, Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Assiut University, Assiut, 71516 Egypt ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A series of CuxCo3−xO4 catalysts were prepared and presented as active and stable catalysts in the oxidation of CO into CO2 at relatively low temperatures. These nanoparticles were synthesized by co-precipitation assisted ultrasonic radiation method. The thermal behavior, structural, spectroscopic, texture, and morphological characterizations were carried out adopting TG-DTA, XRD, XPS, FTIR, N2-sorption, and TEM techniques. In addition, electrical conductivity and surface chemisorbed oxygen measurements were also studied. The quantity and strength of basic sites were estimated using CO2-TPD. The results revealed that the insertion of Cu2+ with values of x from 0.25 to 0.75, into Co3O4 catalysts calcined at 400 °C monotonically increases the SBET, the amount of surface chemisorbed oxygen, catalyst basicity, electrical conductivity and catalytic activity. In addition, the activity increases to an optimal amount of Cu2+ substitution for Co2+ with x = 0.75 which exhibited the most active catalyst with a value of T100 of 125 °C. Results of CO2-TPD demonstrated that, incorporation of Cu2+ with a value of x of 0.75 not only increases the total basicity, but also altered strength and distribution of basic sites over the surface of the catalyst. The role of the active redox sites existed on the surface of these catalysts such as, Co3+/Co2+, Cu2+/Cu+ and Co3+/Cu+, which are accountable for such alteration, was also debated. The most active catalyst Cu0.75Co2.25O4 displayed a long-term stability up to 100 h. Keywords CuxCo3−xO4 CO oxidation CO2-TPD Ultrsonication Long-term Stability 1 Introduction Gassy, fluid, and hard contaminants that released from manufacturing and transportable sources greatly impact the humanoid sustainability and health [1,2]. One, of these harmful gases is the carbon monoxide (CO). CO is an odorless, colorless and faintly lighter than air (about 3%). It is a non-irritant and toxic to all respiring life forms, particularly human's beings and indirectly contribute to global warming and ozone depletion. The toxicity of CO is ascribed to its high affinity for hemoglobin in the blood stream. Accordingly, one of the best means to prevent or governor its environmental contamination and destruction is by oxidizing it to the fewer harming gas, CO2. In this context, catalysts containing noble metals such as gold, platinum, and palladium are the finest catalysts for CO conversion, and are capable of removing it at ambient temperatures [3–6]. Though, these metals are infrequent, more luxurious, and very delicate to S poisoning [7]. Consequently, many efforts have been paid to develop low cost noble metal free catalysts for catalytic CO oxidation at low temperature, such as cobalt, manganese, iron and copper oxides. According to literature [8–17], Co3O4 have been arose as an gorgeous catalyst for CO oxidation due to its ideal CO adsorption strength, low fence for CO reaction with lattice O, and brilliant redox capability owing to the existence of Co3+/Co2+ redox couples. Co3O4 has a spinel structure with Co3+ is octahedrally coordinated and Co2+ tetrahedrally coordinated with a ratio of 2:1 [9]. The first is considered as active spot for CO oxidation while the last is virtually inactive [8,12,15,16]. Therefore, substitution of Co2+ with other divalent cations may present an alternative strategy for improving of the catalytic performance of Co3O4 towards CO oxidation. Metal cobaltites, MxCo3-xO4, belong to a class of materials called composite oxides (comprising 2 or more kinds of Mn+). In the normal spinel, M2+ ions (like Cu, Mg, Mn, Ni, Zn) inhabit the tetrahedral sites which may be improve the catalytic oxidation of CO. Among the divalent metal ions, Cu2+ may be an ideal cation for substituting Co2+ because Cu2+ not only somewhat active for CO oxidation, but also has an ionic radius that is comparable to that of Co2+ (70 and 73 pm for Co2+ and Cu2+, respectively) [8,13]. Moreover, different copper cobaltite spinels are reported to be active catalysts for a class of manufacturing processes, such as decomposition of ammonium perchlorate [18,19], decomposition of N2O [20–23], CO-NO/O2, CO/O2 and CO/NO reactions [24,25], electrocatalyst for O2 evolution [26–28] and CH3OH oxidation [29], burning rate modifier for composite solid propellants [30], recovery and removing of Hg [31], electrocatalytic oxidation of CN− ions [32], synthesis of alcohol, vehicle pollution control and oxygen progress [26,27,33–35], supercapacitors [36], CO, CH4 oxidations and NO decomposition [8,37], and CO reduction [38]. Regrettably so far, to the best of our knowledge, there are no reports considering the catalytic oxidation of CO over ultrasonically prepared CuxCo3-xO4 spinels towards CO oxidation. The ultrasonic radiation was used to increase the particles dispersion, reduce the particles size, decrease the agglomeration and improve the uniformity and stability of the particles. In the ultrasonic radiation process, a cavitation phenomenon was released when a high intensity and low pressure are applied to liquids. Small bubbles were formed, grow with time to a certain size, once they reach the maximum size they rapidly collapse, and high energy is released [39]. This high energy creates high-pressure and high-speed liquid jets [40], which are responsible for violent collisions between the particles, resulting in the formation of very small particles with uniform size and stability [41]. In the present paper, we studied (i) the effect of Cu2+ substitution on the catalytic performance of ultrasonically prepared CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts towards CO oxidation, (ii) development a high surface area CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts capable for converting CO into CO2 at relatively low temperature than that previously reported in literature, (iii) the influence of various operating impacts on the catalytic routine of CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts such as annealing temperature, gas hourly space velocity, feeding conditions and stability. In addition, the relationship between the catalyst structure and the catalytic activity is well correlated and discussed from the view of surface area, surface chemisorbed oxygen, electrical conductivity, basicity measurements and activation energy of conductivity and CO oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts A series of CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts, in which x (mol/mol) = 0.00, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75, 1.00, 1.25, and 3.00 was synthesized by co-precipitation assisted ultrasonic radiation as that previously reported by Said et. al with some modifications [42,43]. Sigma-Aldrich grade chemicals were adopted in solids synthesis. In brief description, a warm aqueous solution of 0.2 M potassium carbonate was dropwisely added into a warm (60 °C) aqueous solution comprising Co(NO3)2.6H2O and/or Cu(NO3)2.3H2O under stirring until a pH of 9.8 ± 2 was obtained. The obtained precipitate was ultrasonically radiated using an ultrasonic generator (Sonics Vibracell with probe, SONICA-2200 E, 20 kHz frequency, and a power of 750 W, USA) for 20 min at 60 °C. The sonicated slurry was stirred for 2 h at this temperature and aged for 1 h. The obtained precipitates are filtered, washed and dried overnight at 110 °C. Based on TG-DTA analysis, all the dried solids are calcined at 400 °C for 3 h in air atmosphere. In addition, depending on the catalytic activity results, the solid precursor with x value of 0.75 was annealed at 500, 600, and 1000 °C. The actual content of Cu in each catalyst was confirmed by Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) spectrometer (iCAP 6200), the results are cited in Table (1), and these data are very close to the theoretical data. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The thermal constancy of the desiccated precursors was explored by thermal analysis to determine the best calcination temperature. TG and DTA investigations were achieved using a "Shimadzu Thermal Analyzer (TA 60H, Japan) apparatus". X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were carried out using a "Philips diffractometer (Model PW 2103, λ = 1.5418 Å, 35 KV and 20 mA) with a CuK α1 radiation source with a Ni Filter". The crystallite size (D) of the prepared catalysts were estimated adopting the well-known Scherer's formula [44]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was collected on K-ALPHA (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with monochromatic X-ray Al K-alpha radiation -10 to 1350 e.v spot size 400 micro m at pressure 10−9 mbar with full spectrum pass energy 200 e.v and at narrow spectrum 50 e.v. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image was recorded using a "TECNAI G2 spirit TWIN (Japan) instrument at 120 KV and connected with VELETA camera". FTIR spectra were recorded at 27 °C in the range of 4000−400 cm−1 on an FTIR spectrophotometer (Thermo-Nicolet model 6700) using the KBr disc technique. Texture assessments were evaluated using the "Quantachrom Instrument Corporation, USA (Model Nova 3200)". The samples were degassed prior to the analysis at 250 °C for 2 h to a residual pressure of 10−5 Torr. The concentration (mg g−1) of the surface chemisorbed oxygen (simply as Osurf) over the surfaces of the prepared catalysts was measured by the scheme that formerly designated [42,43,45]. The electrical conductivity tests were performed as that formerly designated [42,43,46]. The quantity and strength population of basic sites over the surface of these catalysts were evaluated adopting CO2-TPD using a method described by Mekhemer et al. [47] with some modifications. In a brief description, about 500 mg of the catalyst was heated at 200 °C for about 2 h to remove any adsorbed materials and then transferred into an evacuated descator at 10−5 torr. A stream of CO2 gas (99.99 %) was allowed to pass into the desiccator to reach the atmospheric pressure and closed. The catalyst was kept in touch with CO2 for 7 days. The CO2-saturated catalyst undergoing a TGA analysis from room temperature upt to 400 °C in air atmosphere. 2.3 The catalytic oxidation measurements The catalytic oxidation efficiency of the catalysts towards CO was investigated in a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor under atmospheric pressure. The detailed measurements were previously explained [42]. Briefly, "each catalytic run was carried out using 500 mg of the sieved powder catalyst and a mixture of CO (0.2 %) and air was admitted to the reactor at a total flow rate of 150 ml min−1. The outlet gas was analyzed using the Multigas Analyzer (ADC MGA-3000 series, USA)". The efficiency of CO conversion (C) was calculated as reported by the following equation: C O C o n v e r s i o n % = C O in - C O o u t [ C O ] i n X 100 Where [CO]in and [CO]out are the inlet (initial) and outlet CO concentration, respectively. In addition, the CO oxidation activation energy, ΔECO, was also calculated as previously described [43]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 Thermal analysis (TG&DTA) TG and DTA curves of pure basic cobalt carbonate are shown in Fig. 1 (a). Inspection of Fig. 1(a) reveals that, the TG curve possessed three stages. The 1st stage is observed at 25−150 °C range and exhibited a mass loss of 4.8 %. This weight loss is convoyed by an endothermic peak on the DTA curve located at 80 °C. This event is due to the dehydration process to produce the moisture-free solid. The 2nd stage, which in the range of 160−300 °C, associated with a noticeable mass loss of a 22.2 % and is linked with 2 endothermic peaks located at 220 and 280 °C. This period may parallel to the synchronized decomposition of both CoCO3 and Co(OH)2 into Co3O4 [43,48,49]. The third step with a weight loss of 1.4 % happens in the temperature range of 900−950 °C and accompanied with an endothermic peak at 940 °C. Such high temperature weight loss may be credited to the thermal decomposition of Co3O4 to CoO [22,43,49]. TG and DTA curves of pure copper carbonate basic (x = 3.00) are presented in Fig. 1(c). TG curve shows only one step in 30−260 °C range with a mass loss of 27.5 % and is complemented with an endothermic peak on the DTA curve positioned at 225 °C. Such event is qualified to the full decomposition of CuCO3.Cu(OH)2 into CuO as in the following equation [42,50]: CuCO3.Cu(OH)2→ 2CuO + CO2 + H2O Upon growing the heat up to 1000 °C, no other thermal events were detected either on TG or DTA curves, signifying the thermal solidity of the thermally produced CuO. Thermal events that developed throughout the heat action of cobalt/copper basic mixed solid with x = 0.75 are exposed in Fig. 1(b). A close examination of the TG curve shows that the occurrence of three weight losses. The first weight loss (7.5 %) is in the range of 30−205 °C and supplemented with an endothermic peak minimized at 82 °C. Such event is ascribed to the elimination of both physically adsorbed moisture and water of crystallization. The 2nd weight loss with a value of 19.9 % lies within the temperature range of 205−370 °C and exhibited one exothermic peak (with tail) maximized at 315 °C. According to literature [19,22,51,52], and XRD (in the next section), this thermal event corresponds to (i) decomposition of both copper and cobalt carbonate mixture into CuO and Co3O4, respectively, and (ii) solid-solid interaction between CuO and Co3O4 forming CuCo2O4 spinel according to the following equation: 6 CuO + 4 C o 3 O 4 + O 2 ⟶ 400 o C 6 C u 0.92 C o 2.08 O 4 The third weight loss (4.7 %) observed in the temperature range, 860−890 °C, and associated with an endothermic peak at 870 °C may be due to the thermal decomposition of 6Cu0.92Co2.08O4 giving CuO and Co3O4 which may further partially reduced into Cu2O and CoO, respectively [22]. This result specifies that the existence of Cu2+ in CuCo2O4 enhances the thermal reduction of Co3+ into Co2+. This conclusion agrees well with that previously reported in literature [22,51,52]. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The XRD patterns of solids with x = 0.00, x = 3.00 and their mixed solids with x = 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0, and 1.25 calcined at 400 °C were signified in Fig. 2 (a&b). From the results presented in Fig. 2(a), the matching of the diffraction lines of pure cobalt carbonate anneald at 400 °C with that acknowledged in the (JCPDS No. 04-016-4508) demonstrated that the principal diffracted lines situated at d (Å) = 4.687, 2.867, 2.443, 2.025, 1.557 and 1.430 related to the cubic Co3O4 lattice. Additionally, the XRD data of CuCO3.Cu(OH)2 annealed at 400 °C were well harmonized with the data of "JCPDS No.04-015-5877". Thus, the diffraction lines at d(Å) = 2.765, 2.533, 2.523, 2.329, 1.865, 1.586, 1.507 assigned to the monoclinic phase of CuO. Examination of the patterns of copper/cobalt mixtures calcined at 400 °C reveals that, for the catalyst in which x = 0.25, 0.50 and x = 0.75, the diffractograms indicated the occurrence of Cu0.37Co2.63O4 (JCPDS No. 04-021-0314), Cu0.15Co2.84O4 (JCPDS No. 01-078-2172), and Co3O4 (JCPDS No. 04-016-4508) which have peaks that are very close to each other. On raising the value of x to be 1.00 and 1.25, the diffraction patterns match well with that of Cu0.92Co2.08O4 (JCPDS No. 04-007-8055) spinel and CuO. These results confirmed that, no complete dissolution of Cu into the Co3O4 is occurred as reported by chi et al. [52]. Fig. 2(b) displays the XRD diffractograms attained for the solid with x = 0.75 calcined at 400, 500, 600 and 1000 °C. Inspection of this figure illustrates that growing the heat treatment to 500 °C leads to the appearance of CuO phase while further increase the calcination temperature to 600 °C stemmed in a growth in the intensity of all reflections of both spinel and CuO phases. Such increase, in turns, indicates an increase in the catalyst crystallinity. i.e, the appearance of CuO as an isolated segment occurred in the change of CuCo2O4 by heating at 500 °C. This result indicates that, Cu-Co spinel system partially start to decompose by heating at 500 °C as the following equation: 3 CuC o 2 O 4 ⟶ 500 o C 3 CuO +C o 3 O 4 + 1/2 O 2 Upon increasing the calcination temperature to 600 °C, a significant increase in the relative intensity of diffraction peaks of CuO, present as a separate phase, was observed. Pushing the annealing temperature to 1000 °C, results in (i) decreasing the intensity of the diffractions corresponding to both spinel and CuO (ii) appearance of new reflection at 2ө = 42.3° which is attributed to CoO ((JCPDS No. 01-076-3831) sideways with an overgrowth of sharpness of the reflections at 2ө = 73.7 and 77.56° which fit to both Co3O4 and CoO phases. However, the size of the crystallites (DXRD) was estimated and the values were cited in Table (1). The data naked that, the average particle sizes of pure CuO is greater than that of pure Co3O4 while, emerging of CuO into Co3O4 corresponding to x = 0.25,0.50, and 0.75 causing a decrease in the values of DXRD of copper cobaltite spinels. An extra rise in the CuO content (x = 1.00 and 1.25), the average particle sizes increases. In addition, increasing the calcination temperature (for x = 0.75) occasioned an increase in the crystallite sizes indicating agglomeration and densification processes. 3.1.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The chemical composition and the oxidation states of Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst were investigated by XPS and the results are presented in Fig. 3 . The full survey spectrum (Fig. 3a) indicates the presence of C, O, Co, and Cu. The binding energies obtained in the analysis were corrected with the reference to C 1s (284.6 eV). The high-resolution spectrum for the Co 2p region (Fig. 3b) reveals two main peaks at binding energies of 794.5 and 779.6 eV, assigned to Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2, respectively. The main peaks are separated by a spin-energy of 15 eV, indicating the existence of mixed Co2+ and Co3+ [53]. The fitted peaks centered at 781 and 795.8 eV correspond to the binding energy of Co2+, whereas the other two peaks located at 779.4 and 794.3 eV are ascribed to Co3+ signal. The Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 peaks were observed at slightly lower binding energies than those of pure Co3O4 [54], because of the change in the cation distribution at the spinel surface when Co2+ is replaced by Cu2+ ions into the spinel lattice [55]. In the Cu 2p spectrum (Fig. 3c), two main peaks located at 933.7 and 953.8 eV ascribed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 photoemission lines, respectively and a strong satellite signal between them located at 942.5 eV. The Cu2p3/2 is characterized by an asymmetric peak centered at 934.3 eV which corresponded to octahedral Cu2+, and the Cu 2p1/2 component is characterized by a peak at about 954.1 eV. The peak observed at a binding energy of 932.7 eV can be attributed to tetrahedral Cu1+, which comes from the mutual interaction between Co2+ and Cu2+ to give Co3+ and Cu1+ [42,43]. Two shake-up satellite peaks (Sat.) were located at 942.5 and 961.5 eV, confirming the characteristics of Cu2+ [56]. The main Cu 2p peaks are separated by about 20 eV, which attributed to the existence of an open 3d9 shell of Cu2+ [57]. It was reported that Co3O4 in a normal spinel structure has a face-centered cubic (fcc) packing of oxygen anions, with Co3+ filling half the octahedral interstitial sites and Co2+ filling one-eighth of the tetrahedral sites [54]. The substitution of Co ions by foreign divalent transition metals leads to an inhomogeneous distribution of cations and produce a partially inverted spinel structure, with foreign and cobalt ions occupying both octahedral and tetrahedral sites. In the Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst, the peak at 934.2 eV is the most prominent one, which indicates that Cu2+ distributes preferentially over sites with an octahedral coordination [58]. Fig. 3d depicts the O 1s spectrum which was resolved into three components (O1, O2, and O3) with binding energies of 529.24, 530.9, and 531.8 eV. These peaks attributed to the lattice O2− species, surface oxygen, and adsorbed oxygen species, respectively [59]. The surface composition of Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst shows a concentration of both cations close to the expected Co:Cu ratio (3.7:1). The XPS measurements results support the above XRD results. 3.1.4 Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) Fig. 4 displays the FTIR spectra of CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts calcined at 400 °C. The absorption weak broad band observed at 3300-3600 cm−1 may correspond to the OH group on the catalyst surface [60]. FTIR spectrum of pure CuO shows broad bands at 480–486, 530 and at 575 cm−1. These bands may be due to the Cu-O bond in CuO [60]. On the other hand, all the spectra of catalysts with x = 0.00, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75, 1.00, and 1.25 showed the existence of tetrahedral and octahedral fields as elements of spinel lattice, AIIB2 IIIO4. These domains are characterized by the two absorption bands at 650−655 cm−1 and 550−560 cm-1 [19,22,61]. While the spectra of two catalysts with x = 1.00 and x = 1.25, besides the two bands corresponding to spinel, they show a spectral absorption bands at 490 and 503 cm−1, respectively. Such peaks are attributed to CuO phase [60]. FTIR spectra of Cu0.75Co2.25O4 calcined at 500, 600, and 1000 °C, (not shown here, show the presence of the two absorption bands that describing the spinel structure, i.e., 660 and 570 cm−1. In addition, for the catalyst calcined at 1000 °C, a broad peak below 550 cm−1 was detected illustrating the presence of CoO and CuO [22]. These results match well with the finding obtained from TG-DTA and XRD analysis. 3.1.5 Transmission electron microscope (TEM) The morphological investigation and particle size estimation for the catalyst with x = 0.75 calcined at 400 and 600 °C are examined by TEM and the results are displayed in Fig. (5). The micrographs obviously evidence that the formation of particles in nano-dimensions. The spheres size was valued to be around 12–16 and 32−38 nm for the catalyst calcined at 400 and 600 °C, respectively, which are in moral contract with that obtained by the XRD and SBET as exposed in Table (1). The evolution in the particle size between 400 and 600 calcined catalysts may be due to the sintering and agglomeration processes [42,43]. 3.1.6 Texture properties CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms for CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts were measured and presented in Fig. (6) and the resultant texture data are compiled in Table (1). The isotherms (for solids prepared by ultrasonication) shown in Fig. (6) are described by a steep increase in the quantity of gas adsorbed at low values of P/Po and the desorption branch is almost lying on the adsorption one. In addition, the isotherms of catalysts with x = 0.00, and x = 3.00 belong to type II of Brunauer's classification, indicating multilayer adsorption, and exhibited hysteresis loops H3 type [62]. On the other hand, the isotherms of Cu-Co spinel systems fit to type IV of Brunauer's classification and hysteresis loops of H2. Such findings indicate the presence of mesoporosity [62]. The SBET of the catalysts, prepared with and without ultrasonic radiation, calcined at 400 °C, were calculated and mentioned in Table (1) and Fig. 7 (a). Moreover, an alternative group of specific surface areas, St was calculated adopting the Va-t plots [42,43]. The catalysts prepared with ultrasonication exhibits better textural properties. Indeed, the SBET and the pore volume of these catalysts is higher than that of prepared without ultrasonication. Moreover, the average particle size calculated from the surface area measurements decreased with ultrasound treatment. The ultrasonication accelerated the crystal formation and reduced the aggregation during nucleation and crystal growth, giving rise to a large increase in the specific surface area and decrease in the particles size [63]. In the catalysts that prepared by the assistance of sonication pure Co3O4 (x = 0.00) has a value of SBET higher than that of pure CuO (x = 3.00). In addition, increasing the value of x resulted in increasing the SBET to reach a supreme at x = 0.75 (53.6 m2 g−1). Further growth in the value of x is associated with a fall in the value of SBET. Moreover, like attitude in the variation of Vp with x values was also observed. If we assume that the catalyst particles are spheres, hence the theoretical particle sizes could be calculated [42] and the values are given in Table (1). Examination of the calculated data, Table (1), demonstrates that, the introduction of CuO (x = 0.25, 0.50, 0.75) into Co3O4 led to an observable reduction in the particle diameter of the formed catalysts from 19.5–11.2 nm, whereas above this value (x = 1.00 and 1.25), a minor rise in the particle size is identified. These results are agreed with that were calculated from XRD. Accordingly, the developed SBET values of the copper cobaltite catalyst (x = 0.25−0.75) than the pure oxides (x = 0.00 and 3.00) may be ascribed to, the increase in the total pore volume, and the decrease in the particle diameter. The diminution in the SBET for the catalysts with x ≥1.00 may be attributed to (i) the distinctive behavior of low BET-surface area (14.7 m2 g−1) of copper oxide (x = 3.00), (ii) obstructive of some holes of the host oxide, (iii) the reduction in the vp, and (iv) the growth in the particle size as clarified from Table (1). The effect of calcination temperature (400−1000 °C) on the texture properties of the Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst was carried out and the corresponding texture data values are cited in Table (1) and Fig. 8 (a). The obtained data revealed that, on raising the annealing temperature, the catalysts undergo an incessant and severe lessening in the specific surface area (SBET & St) values. Such decrease can be correlated with the process of sintering and densification, initiated by high annealing. 3.1.7 Surface chemisorbed oxygen measurement The quantities of Osurf adsorbed over the surface of pure Co3O4 (x = 0.00), pure CuO (x = 3.00) and Cu-Co spinel catalysts calcined at 400 °C were measured and graphically given in Fig. 7(b). Examination of these results revealed that, at the calcination temperature of 400 °C, the amount of Osurf over pure Co3O4 is greater than that over pure CuO. In addition, the quantity of Osurf of pure Co3O4 gradually increases with the rise of x value to attain a maximum at x = 0.75. Above this maximum, further increase of x value causes a continuous diminution in the value of surface chemisorbed oxygen. As previously reported the observed raising in the amount of Osurf may be credited to a synergistic effect between the two oxides which can be ascribed to the existence of different redox pairs not only Cu2+/Cu+ for CuO, and Co3+/Co2+ for Co3O4, but also Co3+/Cu+ ion pairs in the mixed copper cobaltite spinels as confirmed from XPS analysis [19,42,43,50,51]. The grouping of two oxides leads to creating systems with new physico-chemical properties [51,64] which may exhibit high activity compared to single oxides [50,51,65]. On the other hand, the influence of catalyst thermal treatment on the amount of Osurf over the catalyst with x = 0.75 was studied and displayed in Fig. 8(b). The results showed that growing the annealing temperature above 400 °C, resulted in a substantial diminution in the amount of Osurf. Such decrease may be associated with the fall in the SBET of the catalysts under study [42,43,48]. A good parallelism was observed by comparing these results with that obtained from SBET measurements. 3.1.8 Electrical conductivity measurements The electrical conductivity expressed as a log σ for CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts calcined at 400 °C and those calcined at different temperatures is measured in air atmosphere at a reaction temperature of 125 °C. The variation of log σ with the value of x for the catalysts calcined at 400 °C is displayed in Fig. 7(c). The results demonstrate that the log σ of pure Co3O4 is higher than that of pure CuO whereas its value is gradually increasing with growing the value x from 0.25 to 0.75 to touch an extreme value at x = 0.75. Further increase of x value resulted in a little decrease in the value of log σ. Such behavior may be attributed to the existence of different active redox couples, such as Cu2+/Cu+ (in pure CuO) together with Co2+/Co3+ (in pure Co3O4) which resulted in creation of Cu+/Co3+ active ion pairs, that has a significant role in increasing the electrical conductivity values [19,42,43]. On the other hand, the observed decrease in the electrical conductivity of the Cu-Co spinels upon increasing the x value above 0.75 may be due to the lessening of the mobility charge carriers [42]. However, the values of the activation energy were taken previously [42] as an indicator for the conductivity variations. Thus, plotting of log σ values versus 1/T can be used to estimate the activation energy of conduction, ΔEσ through the straight lines of the well-known Arrhenius relationship as previously calculated [42,43]. The obtained values of ΔEσ are cited in Table (2). These results disclose that the value of ΔEσ of pure CuO is greater than that of pure Co3O4. In addition, as the value of x increases from 0.25 to 0.75, the ΔEσ progressively decreases from 0.21 to 0. 05 eV. A further increase in the value of x leads to an increase in the value of ΔEσ. The observed decrease in ΔEσ values reproduces again the noticeable enrichment of the concentration of the charge carriers (Co3+/Cu+) created within the copper-cobalt spinels with x values of 0.25−0.75. The effect of annealing temperature on both values of log σ and ΔEσ was studied on the catalyst with x = 0.75 and the obtained results are presented in Fig. 8(c) and Table (2). The results clearly reflect that upon raising the heat treatment above 400 °C, a reduction in the value of log σ and increase in the value of ΔEσ are observed. This decrease may be connected with the drop in the values of both SBET and the amount of Osurf [42,43]· 3.1.9 Basicity measurements The results of CO2-TPD of the catalysts under investigation and annealed at 400 °C are given in Table (3). Significant findings could be estimated from these data as follow: (i) the value of total basicity of pure Co3O4 is higher than that of pure CuO, (ii) the value of total basicity increases with the substitution of Co2+ with Cu2+ to reach a maximum at x equal to 0.75, while decrease for further increase, and (iii) the insertion of Cu2+ into Co3O4 not only improve the value of total basicity but also change the distribution of basic sites via shifting the strength of the basic sites to the weak region. Similar results were reported by Biabani-Ravandi et al. [66] indicating that suprafacial mechanism is dominant in CO oxidation over the catalysts under investigation. 3.2 Catalytic oxidation of CO into CO2 Catalytic oxidation of CO into CO2 over CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts has been examined and the results are displayed in Figs. () . Fig. 9(a) presents the dependence of CO conversion on the reaction temperature over ultrasonic radiated CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts calcined at 400 °C. A close check of this figure illustrates that: (i) the catalytic performance of all catalysts exhibited a similar trend that their performances increase with raising the reaction temperature, (ii) the activity of the pure Co3O4 catalyst is higher than that of the pure CuO, where the reaction temperature at which complete CO oxidation to CO2 obtained (T100, Fig. 9(b)) are 225 and 325 °C for pure Co3O4 and pure CuO, respectively, and (iii) the activities of all Cu-Co spinel cobaltites are larger than that of both pure oxides. Additionally, the results shown in Fig. 9(a&b) clearly reveal that, the catalytic behavior of CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts increases with the evolution of x to reach a supreme value at x = 0.75. Overhead this ratio, extra additions of CuO (i.e., x = 1.00 and 1.25) lead to an incessant diminution in the activity of these catalysts. These results also demonstrate that a synergistic effect between oxides was observed, which powerfully influence the catalytic performance of these catalysts. Interestingly, the data reflect that, on a substitution of Co2+ by Cu2+ with x = 0.75, the T100 (Fig. 9(b)) decreases from 225 to 125 °C indicating that a 100 °C is saved. The results also show that, raising the Cu quantity can improve the catalytic behavior of the catalysts to some degree [42]. The reason that the catalytic activity decreases above (x = 0.75) may be associated with the existence of excessive amounts of the less active CuO phase (as shown by XRD). Where the extra copper oxide species may not only shield some of the active centers, but also results in the creation of bulk copper oxide, which could have a harmful influence on the catalytic activity of these catalysts towards CO oxidation [42]. On the other hand, calculating the activation energy of CO oxidation, ΔECO, may give interesting information about the CO oxidation reaction rate over the surface of these catalysts. In these measurements, the reaction temperature was chosen in a range that kept CO conversion below 15 % for realizing a differential reactor assumption [8,42,43]. The obtained values of ΔECO are compiled in Table (2). It is clear from the data that, ΔECO for pure CuO is greater than that of pure Co3O4, while ΔECO values of all Cu-Co spinels are lower than that of pure oxides. In addition, as the value of x increases the value of ΔECO decreases to reach a minimum for the catalyst with x = 0.75 (25.4 kJ/mol). Above this minimum, further growth in the value of x resulted in raising the value of ΔECO. It is well reported "that the high SBET of nanostructured catalysts results in more unsaturated surface coordination sites exposed to the reaction gas so as to enhance the catalyst activity". However, considering the variation of SBET as a function of x (Fig. (7)) the resulting profile of CO oxidation (T100) exhibits almost the same fashion as that of BET surface area. This reflects that the activity performance of the Cu-Co spinel catalysts depends strictly on their SBET. Consequently, the improved activity should be correlated with the increased SBET values initiated by the synergistic effect of both Cu and Co species oxides. Furthermore, the improved activity of Cu-Co spinels catalysts compared to the pure catalysts can also be explained in terms of the concept of bivalent catalytic centers [42]. So, the higher activity of the copper substituted cobalt oxide spinel might be owing to the fact that alongside the one active site, they will be able to produce the mixed sites Cu+/Co3+ ion pairs (as shown from XPS analysis) as a mutual charge interface between Cu2+/Cu+ and Co3+/Co2+ [19,42,43]. Therefore, the existence of Cu2+/Cu+ ratio together with Co2+/Co3+ should enable the electron jumping amongst Cu+/Co3+ active pairs. This electron is caught by O2 molecule on the surface and hence improves the amount of chemisorbed oxygen on the surface of these catalysts (as illustrated in (Fig. 7(b)) and consequently plays a key role in promoting the catalytic performance of Cu-Co spinel catalysts towards CO oxidation at low temperatures. In addition, according to our previous results [42,43], it was found a strong relationship between the basicity & amount of Osurf and the rate of CO oxidation. Accordingly, from the overhead discussion, we can attribute the superior catalytic performance of Cu substituted Co3O4 to: (i) the improvement observed in the values of SBET, electrical conductivity, basicity and surface chemisorbed oxygen Osurf, and (ii) the diminution in the values of particle size, activation energies of conduction and oxidation. In addition, it was previously reported that [8,15,16], within Co3O4 structure, Co3+ is an active site for CO oxidation while Co2+ is inactive. So, the substitution of Co2+ with other divalent leads to an improvement of the catalytic performance. In this concern, Cu2+ may be an ideal regard for substitution Co2+ because Cu2+ not only somewhat active for CO oxidation but also the similar ionic radii of both ions. Moreover, Zhou et al. [8] have stated that, the existence of Cu2+ dopant changed the CO adsorption capacity over Co3+ and oxygen vacancy in Co3+-O-Cu2+ bond became more favorable for CO oxidation than that in Co3+-O-Co2+. Established on the results mentioned above, the catalyst with x = 0.75 is the most active catalyst with T100 of 125 °C, so it was chosen to examine the effect of several operating factors and stability on its catalytic activity. 3.2.1 Effect of time of ultrasonic radiation To explore the impact of ultrasonication time on the catalytic performance of Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst calcined at 400 °C, the obtained precipitate (during the preparation step) of Cu-Co carbonate mixture corresponding to x = 0.75 was subject to different times of ultrasonic radiation, namely, zero time (i.e., without sonication), 10, 20, and 30 min, keeping the frequency amplitude of the ultrasonic radiation is constant. The catalytic activity of each portion calcined at 400 °C is then verified and the results are shown in Fig. 10(a). Analysis of these results reveals that, T100 of all catalysts sonicated at 0, 10, 20, and 30 min are 175, 150, 125, and 125 °C, respectively, which means that ultrasonic radiation at 20 and 30 min reduces the value of T100 by 50 °C and the best sonication time is 20 min. In addition, T100 values for all catalysts without ultrasonic radiation is presented in Fig. 9(b) which manifests the positive and significant effects of sonication. This remarkable improvement may be due to that ultrasonic radiation is preventing the agglomeration of nanoparticles and hence greatly affect the size and morphology of the produced catalysts. 3.2.2 Effect of annealing temperature Calcination temperature could be one of the main factors affecting the activity, textural properties and morphology of heterogeneous catalysts as reported in literature [67]. The effect of annealing temperature on the catalytic performance of Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst towards CO oxidation is performed and the results are depicted in Fig. 10(a). It displays that the catalytic activity of Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst decreases with growing the calcination temperature up to 1000 °C. Also, it can be realized from Fig. 10(b), the catalyst calcined at 400 °C displays a complete CO oxidation at 125 °C. Whereas the catalysts that calcined at 500, 600, and 1000 °C have only 68, 38 and 1 % conversion at a reaction temperature of 125 °C, respectively. Such decrease is consistent with the drastic decrease in SBET and increase in average crystallizes size together with the decrease in the amount of Osurf [42,43], (Fig. 7(b) and Table (1)). 3.2.3 Effect of gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) To study the impact of GHSV on CO oxidation, four changed reaction circumstances were carried out. Fig. 10(c) shows the catalytic behavior of Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst calcined at 400 °C with different GHSVs while keeping CO concentration is constant. As shown in the figure, upon raising the GHSV from 18,000 to 27,000 ml g−1 h−1 led to a successive decline in catalyst efficiency towards CO oxidation. This could be qualified for the low contact time for CO and/or O2 adsorption [42,43]. 3.2.4 Effect of backward and forward feeding conditions It was reported that, "the method of temperature raising or downing along with feeding may have an influence on the shape of the CO conversion graph [66]. Consequently, to observe the effect of temperature-feeding (increase or decrease), the activity was tested over the surface of Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst calcined at 400 °C and the results are given in Fig. 11(a). It shows that the CO conversion trend for both conditions is almost similar. This might be due to the high value of GHSV [42]. This means that, the change from low to high conversion and vice versa is a transitory for this reaction condition over Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst [68–70] 3.2.5 Stability Since, the catalyst stability is a significant topic for the heterogeneous catalysis and the deactivation process during the CO oxidation reaction is a serious problem, especially over Co-based catalysts [12,71], the long-term stability towards the low temperature CO oxidation over Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst calcined at 400 °C was investigated at 125 °C for 100 h and the data are given in Fig. 11(b). It displays that the catalyst under concern has a comparatively high stability under the conditions of reaction towards the complete oxidation of CO after 100 h. In comparison our data to that reported in the literature, there are some interrelated to the catalytic performance of Cu-Co spinel towards CO oxidation [25,37,38,72–74], and the data was summarized in Table (4). In this regard, Stoyanova et al. [25] have prepared and studied the catalytic performance of CuCo2O4/Al2SiO5 catalyst towards CO oxidation. The total conversion of CO into CO2 over this catalyst was achieved at 240 °C. In addition, Stefanova and co-workers [72] have prepared Cu0.9Co2.1O4 deposited on stainless steel as an active catalyst for the complete CO and C3H6 oxidation. They also stated that, only 80 and 40 % conversions are achieved at 400 °C for both CO and C3H6 respectively. Moreover, thin film of CuCo2O4 on grid steel mesh (GSM) have been prepared by Tian et al. [73]. They reported that the obtained catalysts exhibited good thermal stability and excellent catalytic activity towards CO and C3H6 oxidation with complete conversions obtained at 221 and 412 °C, respectively. Recently, Fan et al. [74] have reported that the Cu-Co binary oxides exhibited an excellent catalytic activity with total conversions of both C3H6 and CO at 370 ± 5 and 260 ± 5 °C, respectively. Finally, from our results stated overhead, the lowermost temperature achieved for complete CO conversion over Cu0.75Co2.25O4 catalyst calcined at 400 °C is 125 °C. It is an imperative to remark here that, this temperature is far lower than that previously reported in literature over Cu-Co spinel oxides [25,37,72–74] and comparable with the result of Zhou et al. [8] as illustrated from the comparison established in Table (4). 3.2.6 Mechanism of CO oxidation over CuxCo3-xO4 Literature survey generally accepted that CO oxidation over spinel oxide catalysts follows the Krevelen-type mechanism [75–77]. In such mechanism, formation of a surface oxygen vacancies, via a reduction and re-oxidation, is considered as a key step. Thus, the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies in the solid oxide plays a significant role in the catalytic CO oxidation. On the other hand, according to Tascón et al. [78], Biabani-Ravandi et al. [66] and our results in chemisorbed oxygen and CO2-TPD listed above, the CO oxidation reaction over mixed oxides may also follow a superficial mechanism in which surface lattice oxygen is not involved where the basic sites as surface chemisorbed oxygen is the predominant factor. Thus, the proposed mechanism for CO oxidation over our catalyst may be as the following [79] : (i) Formation of chemisorbed oxygen species that were formed via the presence of different redox couples Cu2+/Cu+ (in pure CuO), Co2+/Co3+ (in pure Co3O4) and Cu+/Co3+ (in CuxCo3-xO4): (E1) O2 (g) + e− → O2 − (ads); O2 − (ads) + e− → 2O− (ads) Adsorption of CO molecules (E2) CO (g) → CO (ads) (ii) Reaction among the adsorbed species to form adsorbed carbonate (E3) CO (ads) + 2O− (ads) → CO3 2− (ads) (iii) Dissociation of adsorbed carbonate and liberation of CO2 product (E4) CO3 2− (ads) → CO2 (ads) + O− (ads) + e− (E5) CO2 (ads) → CO2 (g) 4 Conclusions Conclusions estimated from the above results can be drawn as: • CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts with small particle size, high SBET, high catalytic performance and long-term stability for CO oxidation at low temperature have been effectively synthesized through a simplistic co-precipitation assisted ultrasonication method. • The substitution of Co2+ with Cu2+ (x<1) in the CuxCo3-xO4 catalysts progressively increases the SBET, the amount of surface chemisorbed oxygen, electrical conductivity, and basicity and decreases both values of ΔEσ and ΔECO of CuxCo3-xO4. • The activity of CuxCo3-xO4 spinel catalysts in CO oxidation reaction was found meaningfully influenced by the ultrasonic radiation, annealing temperature, feeding conditions and GHSV. • The most active catalyst, Cu0.75Co2.25O4, calcined at 400 °C exhibits a superior catalytic performance with a complete oxidation of CO at 125 °C and high long-term stability for 100 h. • The significant catalytic performance was associated well with the observed enhancement in the SBET, the amount of Osurf, catalyst basicity electrical conductivity and the decrease in ΔECO and ΔEσ. coredata.dc:description: A series of CuxCo3−xO4 catalysts were prepared and presented as active and stable catalysts in the oxidation of CO into CO2 at relatively low temperatures. These nanoparticles were synthesized by co-precipitation assisted ultrasonic radiation method. The thermal behavior, structural, spectroscopic, texture, and morphological characterizations were carried out adopting TG-DTA, XRD, XPS, FTIR, N2-sorption, and TEM techniques. In addition, electrical conductivity and surface chemisorbed oxygen measurements were also studied. The quantity and strength of basic sites were estimated using CO2-TPD. The results revealed that the insertion of Cu2+ with values of x from 0.25 to 0.75, into Co3O4 catalysts calcined at 400 °C monotonically increases the SBET, the amount of surface chemisorbed oxygen, catalyst basicity, electrical conductivity and catalytic activity. In addition, the activity increases to an optimal amount of Cu2+ substitution for Co2+ with x = 0.75 which exhibited the most active catalyst with a value of T100 of 125 °C. Results of CO2-TPD demonstrated that, incorporation of Cu2+ with a value of x of 0.75 not only increases the total basicity, but also altered strength and distribution of basic sites over the surface of the catalyst. The role of the active redox sites existed on the surface of these catalysts such as, Co3+/Co2+, Cu2+/Cu+ and Co3+/Cu+, which are accountable for such alteration, was also debated. The most active catalyst Cu0.75Co2.25O4 displayed a long-term stability up to 100 h.
coredata.dc:title: The catalytic performance of ultrasonically prepared CuxCo3−xO4 catalysts towards CO oxidation at relatively low temperature
